Editor's choice paper A solvent-free method to rapidly synthesize CuO-CeO2 catalysts to enhance their CO preferential oxidation: Effects of Cu loading and calcination temperature Jing Wang a b Liping Zhong a Jichang Lu a Ran Chen a Yanqiu Lei a Kezhen Chen a Caiyun Han a Sufang He a c ⁎⁎ Gengping Wan a d Yongming Luo a ⁎ a Faculty of Environmental Science and Engineering, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming 650500, PR China Faculty of Environmental sScience and Engineering Kunming University of Science and Technology Kunming 650500 PR China b College of Life Science and Environment, Hengyang Normal University, Hengyang 421008, PR China College of Life Science and Environment Hengyang Normal University Hengyang 421008 PR China c Research Center for Analysis and Measurement, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming 650093, PR China Research Center for Analysis and Measurement Kunming University of Science and Technology Kunming 650093 PR China d Research Center for Analysis and Measurement, Hainan University, Haikou 570228, PR China Research Center for Analysis and Measurement Hainan University Haikou 570228 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. ⁎⁎ Corresponding author at: Faculty of environmental science and engineering, Kunming University of Science and Technology, Kunming 650500, PR China. Graphical abstract A facile and solvent-free route has been developed to rapidly synthesize CuO-CeO2 catalysts within 30min. The effect of calcination temperature on catalytic performances is more significant than Cu loading, and the optimal calcination temperature and Cu loading are 700°C and 7.5wt.%, respectively. The optimal catalyst 7.5CuCe-SF-700 exhibits the highest CO conversion and the corresponding temperature window for full CO conversion is as wide as 50°C. According to the characterization results of XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption, H2-TPR, TEM, HR-TEM, STEM, EDS, Raman and XPS, it can be concluded that the high-performances of CuO-CeO2 catalyst should be attributed to synergistic effects of high dispersion Cu species and CeO2, and the presence of more reduced copper species as the active site in the catalyst. 7.5CuCe-SF-700 exhibits excellent stability for CO-PROX during the 200 time-on-stream test under actual reaction conditions (with 15% CO2 and 10% H2O). In addition, surfactant template, urea gelation/co-precipitation and sol-gel methods were used to synthesize CuO-CeO2 catalysts so as to compare them with 7.5CuCe-SF-700, and the results exhibit not only 7.5CuCe-SF-700 is superior to the former three catalysts but also our synthesis route is more simple, controllable, solvent-free, time-saving and energy-saving. Keywords CuO-CeO2 Solvent-free Calcination temperature Cu loading 1 Introduction Nowadays, fossil fuels are deeply depended on to power and sustain all businesses and services in the world. However, the massive consumption of fossil fuels not only leads to its rapid depletion but also causes serious environmental problems. Developing alternative and renewable energy together with improving energy efficiency are of particular importance to achieve sustainable and environment-friendly energy. Fuel cell, including the types of solid oxide, proton exchange membrane (PEM), phosphoric acid and direct methanol fuel cells, is one of the most promising methods to improve energy efficiency. In particular, the proton exchange membrane fuel cell (PEMFC) has been widely studied to generate on-board electric power for vehicular use and the residential power-generation. However, PEMFC generally suffers from the serious poison of the platinum anode caused by a trace amount (100ppm) of CO in H2-rich streams [1]. Therefore, it is especially important to remove CO from H2-rich gas to ensure the application of PEMFC. As well documented, CO preferential oxidation (CO-PROX) is the most effective and simplest method for removing CO from H2-rich streams, and the noble metal catalyst is one of the most effective catalysts for CO-PROX [2]. Nevertheless, the high cost and limited resources restrict its extensive applications. Recently, the use of CuO-CeO2 catalyst as a promising substitute for noble metal catalyst has been widely studied for CO-PROX [3–7]. It was proved that CuO-CeO2 catalyst for CO-PROX is relatively structure-sensitive and both CuO and CeO2 species play essential roles in determining its catalytic behaviors [8–11]. Moreover, the physicochemical and structural properties of CuO and CeO2 species within CuO-CeO2 catalyst are closely depend on the synthesis method, thus resulting in the distinct difference of catalytic performances [12–14]. Furthermore, CuO-CeO2 catalyst generally suffers from the drawbacks of low activity under low temperature region and narrow temperature window (5–20°C) for the full conversion of CO [15–18]. In order to obtain CuO-CeO2 catalyst with high-performances so to solve these problems, many synthesis routes have been developed in the past decades, which involve impregnation, deposition-precipitation, sol-gel, co-precipitation, inverse co-precipitation, urea gelation/co-precipitation method, and so on [3,19–21]. Despite significant improvement in the low-temperature activity, however, these syntheses routes not only are relatively complex but also energy and time-consuming. In this paper, a facile and solvent-free route was reported to rapidly synthesize CuO-CeO2 catalysts with high-performances, and the key parameters of Cu loading and calcination temperature were investigated to achieve the controllable synthesis. The catalysts were characterized by N2 adsorption-desorption, XRD, H2-TPR, TEM, HR-TEM, STEM, EDS, Raman and XPS. Furthermore, the optimal catalyst (7.5CuCe-SF-700) was carried out the experiment of 200h time-on-stream to estimate the stability under the actual reaction conditions (the presence of 15% CO2 and 10% H2O within the reaction system). In addition, another three methods (surfactant template, urea gelation/co-precipitation and sol-gel methods) were also employed to prepare CuO-CeO2 catalysts to highlight the advantages of our synthesis route. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation A solvent-free (SF) method was used to prepare CuO-CeO2 catalyst samples, which was briefly depicted as follows: the calculated amounts of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (0.045mol), Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.0126mol) and (NH2)2CO (0.114mol) were mixed and grinded at room temperature (RT) to form the transparent viscous gel within a few minutes. Then, the resulting gel was calcined at the 700°C for 20min. This catalyst sample was denoted as 10CuCe-SF-700. In order to investigate the effects of calcination temperature and Cu loading, the corresponding Cu loading and specific calcination temperature were fixed. The catalyst samples prepared by this route were denoted as XCuCe-SF-T, where “X” and “T” are the loading of Cu (wt.%) and calcination temperature (°C), respectively. For comparison purposes, CuO-CeO2 catalysts (Cu loading of 7.5wt%) were prepared by other three methods that involve surfactant template, urea gelation/co-precipitation and sol-gel. The detailed synthesis processes of these three methods were described in Electronic Supplementary Information, and the corresponding catalyst samples were nominated as 7.5CuCe-ST-700, 7.5CuCe-UGC-700 and 7.5CuCe-SG-700, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization A N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms was measured on a Nova 2000 instrument at −196°C. Prior to analysis, all the catalyst samples were degassed under high vacuum at 250°C for 2h. Specific surface area (SBET) was determined by following Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method according to the data of adsorption branch at the relative pressure ranging from 0.05 to 0.25 and the corresponding pore size distribution was calculated by employing the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method on the basis of the desorption branch data. X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern was carried out on a Rigaku D/max-1200 diffractometer by using Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.5406Å) at 2θ range between 10 and 90°. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) and Scanning tunneling electron microscopy (STEM) images were recorded by using a Tecnai G2 TF30 S-Twin microscope equipped with an X-ray Energy Dispersion Spectrometer (EDS), operating with an accelerating voltage of 300kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was employed to measure the surface element compositions together with the corresponding chemical states of all the samples, which was performed with non-monochromatic Al Kα radiation (1486.6eV) as the excitation X-ray source on a PHI 5000 VersaProbe II. The C 1s photoelectron peak at 284.6eV was used as a reference to calibrate binding energy.Raman spectra were recorded by using a Via Reflex Confocal Raman microscope with a laser (514nm) operating at 5mV power. H2-TPR (hydrogen temperature programmed reduction) experiment was performed in a fixed-bed reactor. Before H2-TPR test, 50mg of catalyst sample was pretreated with 5 vol% O2 within argon (Ar) at 400°C for 1h. Next to, the pretreated sample was cooled to 100°C in the flow of ultra-pure argon. After that, H2-TPR analysis was carried out within the flow of 10% H2/Ar (30mL/min) by increasing temperature of reaction system from 100°C to 500°C with a heating rate of 10°C/min, and the consumption of H2 was monitored by an on-line TCD detector. 2.3 Catalytic activity measurement CO-PROX in H2-rich gas was performed in a micro-reactor under atmospheric pressure, and 300mg of catalyst sample with the average particle of 40–60mesh was loaded in the reactor for each test. The feed gas mixture (1% CO, 1% O2, 50% H2 and balanced with He) is introduced with the total flow rate of 80mL/min, corresponding to a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 24000h−1. The excess factor of oxygen within the feed was denoted in terms of the parameter λ, which was defined as λ=2×O2/CO (mole ratio, λ=2). To study the effect of CO2 and H2O on catalytic activity, the corresponding experiments were carried out by the addition of 15% CO2 and 10% H2O into the reaction system, respectively. The outlet gas from the reactor was measured by an online gas chromatography, which was equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD), a flame ionization detector (FID) together with a methanation reactor. The catalytic performances are expressed in terms of CO conversion (%) and CO2 selectivity (%) (the selectivity of O2 to CO2). Conversion and selectivity were calculated on the basis of CO and O2 consumption, as described below: (1) CO conversion ( % ) = [ CO ] in − [ CO ] out [ CO ] in × 100 (2) CO 2 selectivity ( % ) = 0.5 × ( [ CO ] in − [ CO ] out ) [ O 2 ] in − [ O 2 ] out × 100 Where [CO]in and [CO]out are the concentrations of CO (%(v/v)) in the feed stream and the effluent, respectively, [O2]in and [O2]out are the concentrations of O2 (%(v/v)) in the feed stream and the effluent, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Influence of calcination temperature and Cu loading 3.1.1 Catalytic performances It was well demonstrated that calcination temperature is one of the most important factors affecting adsorption and catalytic behaviors of materials [22–25]. Therefore, the effect of calcination temperature on catalytic performances of CuO-CeO2 catalysts prepared with solvent-free method was firstly investigated, and the corresponding CO conversion and CO2 selectivity of 10CuCe-SF-300, 10CuCe-SF-500, 10CuCe-SF-700 and 10CuCe-SF-800 are illustrated in Fig. 1 . It is noted that the calcination temperature plays an important role in determining the catalytic performances of these CuO-CeO2 catalysts, particularly in low-temperature range. The conversion of CO increases with calcination temperature increasing from 300 to 700°C. Further increasing calcination temperature to 800°C, the decrease in the conversion of CO is observed. In general, the conversions of CO over these four catalysts are in the order of 10CuCe-SF-700>10CuCe-SF-500>10CuCe-SF-800>10CuCe-SF-300. The corresponding temperature window for complete conversion of CO over 10CuCe-SF-700 is about 50°C, which is wider than other three catalysts. And 50°C is a wider temperature window, comparable to the CuO-CeO2 catalysts reported in previous documents (Table S1). Therefore, it can draw a conclusion that the optimal calcination temperature is 700°C. Once the optimal calcination temperature is determined, the interrelationship between the loading of Cu and catalytic performances for CO-PROX in H2-rich streams was investigated. A series of XCuCe-SF-700 catalyst samples (5CuCe-SF-700, 7.5CuCe-SF-700 10CuCe-SF-700 and 15CuCe-SF-700) prepared with solvent-free method were tested for CO-PROX, and the corresponding CO conversions and CO2 selectivity of them are presented in Fig. 2 . As can be seen from Fig. 2A, the conversion of CO in low-temperature range slight increases with the loading of Cu increasing from 5wt.% to 7.5wt.%, however, the slight decrease in the conversion of CO is detected for the samples with further increasing Cu loading from 7.5wt.% to 15wt.%. Furthermore, it is noticeable that the CO2 selectivity of 7.5CuCe-SF-700 is comparable to that of 5CuCe-SF-700, 10CuCe-SF-700 and 15CuCe-SF-700. Therefore, it can be deduced that the optimal loading of Cu is about 7.5wt.%. As can be seen by comparing Figs. 1 and 2, it can be concluded that the effect of calcination temperature with respect to Cu loading on catalytic performances of CuO-CeO2 catalysts for CO-PROX is more significant. 3.1.2 Characterization of catalysts X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of four samples calcined at various temperatures (10CuCe-SF-300, 10CuCe-SF-500, 10CuCe-SF-700 and 10CuCe-SF-800) are displayed in Fig. 3 A. The nine diffraction peaks (2θ=28.5, 33.1, 47.5, 56.3, 59.1, 69.4, 76.7, 79.1 and 88.5°) in the XRD patterns of all the four samples correspond to the typically cubic fluorite structure of CeO2 with the reflections of (111), (200), (220), (311), (222), (400), (331), (420) and (422) planes (ICDD 34-0394) [26,27], respectively. Moreover, two diffraction peaks related to the characteristics of CuO phase (2θ=35.6 and 38.8°) [7,28] are detected in the XRD pattern of 10CuCe-SF-800, but not in the patterns of 10CuCe-SF-300, 10CuCe-SF-500 and 10CuCe-SF-700, thus implying bulk CuO phase was formed within 10CuCe-SF-800. This is probably because that high temperature calcination would lead to the sintering of small size CuO particles on the surface of CeO2, thus lowering its catalytic activity. Furthermore, it is noticeable that the increase in the intensity of diffraction peaks is observed for these three catalyst samples with the increasing calcination temperature from 500 to 800°C, which should be closely associated with the formation of the larger crystallite size [26] accompanied with the smaller specific surface area, as further confirmed in Table 1 . The crystallite sizes of them are in the order of 10CuCe-SF–800>10CuCe-SF–700>10CuCe-SF-500. On the other hand, as can be seen from Table 1, with the increasing calcination temperature from 500 to 800°C, an increase in the lattice parameter is detected for 10CuCe-SF-500, 10CuCe-SF-700 and 10CuCe-SF-800. It was documented that the smaller lattice parameter was formed when the more Cu2+ ions with smaller radius (0.73Å) with respect to Ce4+ ions (0.97Å) were entered into the lattice of CeO2 [18,29]. The CeO2 lattice shrinks with the incorporation of copper while it expands with not only the isolation of copper species but partial reduction of CeO2. Based on the increase of the lattice parameter of CeO2 from 500 to 800°C, it can be concluded that less copper ions were incorporated into the lattice of CeO2. Upon the incorporation of foreign metal ions into the ceria matrix, the diffraction lines slightly shifted to higher 2θ values, which correspond to a slight decrease in the lattice constants. It is noted that the position of (111) plane reflection shifts slightly toward the smaller 2θ value with the increase of calcination temperature (Fig. 3A inset). This observation is in good agreement with the lattice parameters obtained from Rietveld analysis. The changes both in the lattice parameter and the position of (111) plane reflection with calcination temperature should be due to the fact that the less copper ions were incorporated into the lattice of CeO2, thus resulting in the non-uniform distribution and further agglomeration of copper species to form bulk CuO on the catalyst surface during high temperature calcination. The difference between 10CuCe-SF-300 and the other three catalysts (10CuCe-SF-500, 10CuCe-SF-700 and 10CuCe-SF-300) might be owing to the fact that the stable solid solution was not formed under the excessively low calcination temperature. In addition, combined with the catalytic activities of 10CuCe-SF-500, 10CuCe-SF-700 and 10CuCe-SF-800, it was found that the formation of bulk CuO on catalysts’ surface would lead to the decline in the catalytic activity to some degree. XRD patterns of 5CuCe-SF-700, 7.5CuCe-SF-700, 10CuCe-SF-700 and 15CuCe- SF-700 are presented in Fig. 3B. As can be seen by comparing XRD patterns of 5CuCe-SF-700 and 7.5CuCe-SF-700, it is noted that the corresponding intensities of all the XRD diffraction peaks of 7.5CuCe-SF-700, ascribed to the characteristics of CeO2 with cubic fluorite structure, are weaker than those of 5CuCe-SF-700, thus implying the smaller crystallite size was formed with the increase of Cu loading from 5wt.% to 7.5wt.%. This is likely because that more amounts of copper cation (Cu2+) with smaller radius were successfully incorporated into the lattice of CeO2. There were no significant changes both in XRD peak intensities and linewidths with further increasing the loading of Cu from 7.5wt.% to 15wt.%. The diffraction peaks assigned to bulk CuO phase with characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 35.6 and 38.8° are obviously expressed in the XRD pattern of 15CuCe-SF-700, suggesting the bulk CuO was formed within this catalyst sample. On the other hand, as can be seen by comparing Table 1, there is a slight decrease in the lattice parameter of 7.5CuCe-SF-700 compared with 5CuCe-SF-700, and a progressive increase in the lattice parameter is observed with further increasing the loading of Cu from 7.5wt.% to 15wt.%. But compared to the increase of Cu loading from 7.5wt.% to 10wt.%, the change in the lattice parameter is rather small from 10wt.% to 15wt.%. The change in the lattice parameter observed herein can be explained as follows: the moderate loading of Cu will be in favor of the incorporation more Cu2+ ions into the lattice of CeO2, whereas the excessive loading of Cu will be beneficial to block the insertion of copper species into the lattice of CeO2, thus causing the accumulation of them on the surface of the catalysts (even CuO phase are obviously expressed in the XRD pattern of 15CuCe-SF-700). Fig. 4 provides TEM and HR-TEM images of 10CuCe-SF-700 and 10CuCe-SF-800. As shown in Fig. 4a, near-spherical shape particles are detected and the corresponding particle size of them ranges from 5 and 15nm. As can be seen from Fig. 4b, representative images of CeO2 nanoparticles are observed, in which the lattice spacing of 0.322nm can be clearly seen [30,31]. As can be seen by comparing Fig. 4c and a, the obvious increase in the particle size is detected for 10CuCe-SF-800. Meanwhile, by comparing Fig. 4d and b, a slight decrease in the lattice spacing is observed for 10CuCe-SF-800 (0.320nm) with respect to 10CuCe-SF-700 (0.322nm). Moreover, the corresponding lattice defect of 10CuCe-SF-800 is significantly reduced compared to 10CuCe-SF-700, which might be due to the facts that the more copper species were migrated from the lattice of CeO2 to the surface and the growth of CeO2 crystals results in the restoration of the defect during high temperature calcination. TEM and HR-TEM images of 5CuCe-SF-700 and 7.5CuCe-SF-700 are presented in Fig. 5 . As for 5CuCe-SF-700, some large particles could be seen in the upper part of Fig. 5a, while most particles are smaller than them (shown in Fig. 5b and the lower part of Fig. 5a). In order to obtain insight into the difference between the small and large particles, the STEM-EDS characterization was used to investigate them. As displayed in Fig. 6 A, the points (a)–(c) were located at the large, the smaller and the smallest particles of 5CuCe-SF-700, respectively. As shown in Fig. 6B, the EDS profiles of (a)–(c) were recorded from the corresponding points (a)–(c) in Fig. 6A. All EDS analysis results of points (a)–(c) are summarized in Table 2 . It is clear that both the content of Cu and the ratio of Cu/Ce are in the order of (c)>(b)>(a). Therefore, it can be concluded that the smaller size of the particle is in favor of the incorporation of copper ions into the lattice of CeO2. Compared with 5CuCe-SF-700, the larger particles of 7.5CuCe-SF-700 disappear, which might be due to the fact that the more incorporation of Cu species into the lattice of CeO2 is beneficial to grain refinement. H2-TPR profiles of 10CuCe-SF-300, 10CuCe-SF-500, 10CuCe-SF-700 and 10CuCe-SF-800 are illustrated in Fig. 7 A. Two H2 consumption peaks (peak β1 and β2) are expressed in the profile of 10CuCe-SF-300. Compared with 10CuCe-SF-300, three reduction peaks (peak α, β1 and β2) are detected in the profile of 10CuCe-SF-500, while two reduction peaks (peak α and β2) are observed in the profile of the sample 10CuCe-SF-700. As for 10CuCe-SF-800, only one highest-temperature reduction peak (peak γ) is found in its profile. The existence of several reduction peaks for the 10CuCe-SF-T catalyst samples calcined at different temperature is an indication of more than one Cu species presented within these catalysts. It was reported [32] that two reduction peaks, located at temperature range of 125–175°C and ∼200°C, have been assigned to copper oxide clusters interacted with the support of ceria and larger CuO particles non-associated with ceria, respectively. Analogous phenomena were reported by Ratnasamy et al. [33], where two peaks have been ascribed to the reduction of highly dispersed CuO clusters interacted with CeO2 and CuO particles. Tang and co-workers [34] reported that three reduction peaks were observed within the H2-TPR profiles of CuO-CeO2 based catalysts, and these reduction peaks from low to high temperature have been attributed to the reduction of high dispersion CuO and larger CuO species on the surface of CeO2, bulk CuO together with the surface species of CeO2, respectively. In addition, Avgouropoulos and Ioannides [35] reported three overlapping reduction peaks: the first peak around 168°C has been ascribed to reduction of copper ions interacted with CeO2; the second reduction peaks at temperature range between 210 and 255°C has been assigned to the reduction of larger CuO particles weakly interacted with the support of ceria. Based on previous reports and our experimental results, the peak α would be attributed to the reduction of high dispersion CuO species interacted with CeO2. Peaks β1 and β2 might be assigned to the larger CuO particles with different particle size, and the peak γ has been ascribed to the reduction of bulk CuO. The appearance of peak α and the shift of all reduction peaks to low temperature for 10CuCe-SF-500 with respect to 10CuCe-SF-300, which might be associated with the formation of highly dispersed CuO species strongly interacting with CeO2 as well as the interaction between CuO and CeO2 was strengthened. Compared with 10CuCe-SF-500, the peak α of 10CuCe-SF-700 shifts to lower-temperature whereas peak β shifts to high-temperature, thus suggesting a stronger interaction between CuO and CeO2 was formed. When calcination temperature further increase to 800°C, the corresponding reduction peak of 10CuCe-SF-800 grown into a single peak, which might be due to the sintering of Cu species to form bulk CuO on the surface, thus inhibiting highly dispersed copper oxide formed and the interaction between highly dispersed CuO and CeO2, and even blocking the active site of Cu-Ce interface. The result in reduction peak change of 10CuCe-SF-800 is excellent in agreement with XRD and TEM characterization. In addition, sintering Cu species not only affects the CO oxidation reaction but also inhibits H2 oxidation by covering the active site, which results in the higher CO2 selectivity of 10CuCe-SF-800 than the other 10wt.% CuCe catalysts. H2-TPR profiles of 5CuCe-SF-700, 7.5CuCe-SF-700, 10CuCe-SF-700 and 15CuCe- SF-700 are shown in Fig. 7B. Only one peak (called peak β) corresponding to the reduction of larger CuO particles weakly associated with CeO2 is observed in the profile of 5CuCe-SF-700. The result indicates that highly dispersed copper species strongly interacted with CeO2 was not formed within 5CuCe-SF-700, which is due to the low Cu loading and is consistent with the result of TEM. As for 7.5CuCe-SF-700 and 10CuCe-SF-700, there are two reduction peaks (named peak α and β) in their profiles, which represented the reduction of highly dispersed CuO species strongly interacted with CeO2 and larger CuO particles weakly associated with CeO2, respectively. The result means that the highly dispersed copper oxide strongly interacted with CeO2 was formed with the increase of copper loading from 5wt.% to 10wt.%. Only one higher-temperature reduction peak (peak γ), ascribed to the reduction of bulk CuO, is expressed in the profile of 15CuCe-SF-700, which should be related to the excessive accumulation of Cu species on the surface of CeO2 to block the formation of stronger interaction between Cu species and CeO2. The phenomena of appearance and disappearance of peak α together with the occurrence of peak γ with the increase of Cu loading from 5wt.% to 15wt.% are well in kept with the characterization results of XRD and TEM that Cu species will first be dispersed and/or inserted into the lattice of CeO2, then the accumulation and agglomeration of Cu species to form bulk CuO was occurred on the surface when Cu species was no longer incorporated into the lattice of CeO2 with increasing the loading of Cu. In addition, it is noted that the reduction peak gradually shifts toward higher temperature with increasing the loading of Cu from 7.5wt.% to 15wt.%, which might be associated with the fact that the decrease of the interaction between CuO and CeO2 to form larger CuO particle and/or bulk CuO. Raman characterization is an effective method to obtain deep insight into the formation of oxygen vacancy defects within Ce-based catalytic materials [36–39]. Raman spectra of 10CuCe-SF-300, 10CuCe-SF-500, 10CuCe-SF-700 and 10CuCe-SF-800 are shown in Fig. 8 A, and the corresponding area ratio of A599 to A462 of them is presented in Fig. 8B. All samples show an intense band around 462cm−1, which has been ascribed to the F2g Raman vibrational mode of O atom surrounded by Ce ions (Ce-O8 unit), implying the existence of cubic fluorite-type structure CeO2 [40,41]. The broad peak located around 599cm−1 is closely linked to the formation of oxygen vacancy defects or structural defects within the lattice of CeO2 [42,43]. The area ratio of band 599cm−1 and 462cm−1 is the characteristic of the relative content of oxygen vacancy defects within materials (designated as A599/A462) [44–46]. Generally, oxygen vacancy defects have a positive effect on catalytic behaviors of CO preferential oxidation [47], and the formation of more oxygen vacancy defects should be beneficial to improve the performances of catalysts [29,41]. As shown in Fig. 8B, the ratio of A599/A462 increases with calcination temperature when it is below 700°C. In general, more Cu2+ ions were incorporated into the lattice of CeO2, the more defective sites were formed within Ce-based materials [18]. Therefore, it can be inferred that the increase ratio of A599/A462 with calcination temperature is an indication that more Cu2+ ions were inserted into the lattice of CeO2. However, compared with the former three catalysts (10CuCe-SF-300, 10CuCe-SF-500 and 10CuCe-SF-700), a significant decline in the ratio of A599/A462 is observed for 10CuCe-SF-800, which should be closely related to the fact that high temperature calcination prevents Cu species from entering the lattice of CeO2, thereby promoting their accumulation and sintering to form bulk CuO on the surface. The changes in the ratio of A599/A462 are well consistent with the results of XRD, H2-TPR and TEM characterizations. Furthermore, the amount of oxygen vacancy defects is closely related to the size of CeO2 particle, and the smaller size is conducive to the formation of more oxygen vacancies [48,49]. X-ray Photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) is employed to obtain further information about the chemical state of Cu and Ce species as well as their compositions on the surface of CuO-CeO2 catalysts by examining the spectral line shape and the intensities of Ce 3d and Cu 2p core level electrons. Cu 2p core level XP spectra of 10CuCe-SF-300, 10CuCe-SF-500, 10CuCe-SF-700 and 10CuCe-SF-800 are shown in Fig. 9 A, and the corresponding Cu 2p core level peak-differentation-imitating spectra are displayed in Fig. S1 (in Supplementary material). An intense Cu 2p3/2 peak centered arounds 933eV is observed for each of them, which can be decomposed into the two peaks according to the binding energy at range of 932.2–933.1eV and greater than 933.1eV, respectively. These two contributions could be assigned to the presence of Cu+ and Cu2+ species, respectively [9,50,51], suggesting the coexistence of two copper species within all the four samples. The existence of reduced copper species within CuO-CeO2 catalysts can be further illustrated by the ratio of the intensity of shake-up satellite to the intensity of the main Cu 2p3/2 peak (designated as Isat/Imp). If only Cu2+ species (such as CuO) was presented, the Isat/Imp ratio should be 0.55. Corresponding Isat/Imp ratios of 10CuCe-SF-300, 10CuCe-SF-500, 10CuCe-SF-700 and 10CuCe-SF-800 are tabulated in Table 3 . As can be seen from Table 3, all the Isat/Imp values of them are lower than 0.55 [52], suggesting the presence of reduced copper (Cu+) species within all the four catalyst samples. It may be ascribed to the strong interaction between CeO2 and highly dispersed CuO, and CO adsorbs on the Cu+ sites over the CuCe catalysts [19]. Moreover, the corresponding ratios of Isat/Imp for the four catalyst samples are as follows: 10CuCe-SF-700<10CuCe-SF-500<10CuCe-SF-800<10CuCe-SF-300, indicating that the relative amounts of reduced copper (Cu+) species in them are in follow order: 10CuCe-SF-700>10CuCe-SF-500>10CuCe-SF-800>10CuCe-SF-300, which is excellent consistent with their catalytic activities (Fig. 1A). Combined with the previous report, the reduced copper species might be attributed to the formation of strong interaction between them and the support CeO2 [19]. Therefore, it can be deduced that the more reduced copper species should be responsible for the higher activity as the active site of catalysts. Analogous phenomena were also reported by other research groups [9–11]. Moreover, the atom ratio of Cu/Ce (seen in Table 3) on the surface of the catalyst is increased with the calcination temperature from 500 to 800°C, implying the increase of copper species on the surface of catalysts. It is in agreement with the conclusion of XRD (the fact that the less copper ions were incorporated into the lattice of CeO2, thus resulting in dispersion, agglomeration and sintering of copper species on the catalyst surface). Cu 2p core level XP spectra of 5CuCe-SF-700, 7.5CuCe-SF-700 and 10CuCe-SF-700 are displayed in Fig. 9B, and the corresponding Isat/Imp ratios of them are also summarized in Table 3. It is noted that the Cu 2p spectra of the three catalyst samples (5CuCe-SF-700, 7.5CuCe-SF-700 and 10CuCe-SF-700) are similar to those of 10CuCe-SF-300, 10CuCe-SF-500, 10CuCe-SF-700 and 10CuCe-SF-800. Based on the corresponding Isat/Imp ratios (Table 3), the relative amounts of reduced copper (Cu+) species are as follows: 7.5CuCe-SF–700>10CuCe-SF–700>5CuCe-SF-700, which is well in agreement with their low-temperature catalytic activities (Fig. 2A). Fig. 10 shows Ce 3d core level XP spectra of both 10CuCe-SF-T (10CuCe-SF-300, 10CuCe-SF-500, 10CuCe-SF-700 and 10CuCe-SF-800) and XCuCe-SF-700 (5CuCe-SF-700, 7.5CuCe-SF-700 and 10CuCe-SF-700). Eight peaks associated with the four pairs of spin-orbit doublets are observed for all studied catalyst samples. The peaks marked as v (from v to v”’) and those labeled as u (from u to u”’) are associated with the 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 spin-orbit components, respectively. The photoelectron peaks v (882.4eV), v” (888.7eV), v”’ (898.3eV), u (900.9eV), u” (907.8eV) and u”’ (916.7eV) have been attributed to the Ce4+ species, and the rest of two peaks v’ (884.5eV) and u’ (903.1eV) are characteristics of the Ce3+ species [53,54]. It was reported that the existence of Ce3+ is closely correlated with the formation of oxygen vacancy defects [53]. It was documented that the high ratio of Ce3+/(Ce4+ +Ce3+) would promote oxygen mobility and thus improve the activity of the catalyst [55]. The percentages of Ce3+ within all the catalyst samples are calculated by means of XPS-peak-differentation-imitating analysis, and the corresponding results are summarized in Table 3. As for the series of 10CuCe-SF-T catalyst samples (10CuCe-SF-300, 10CuCe-SF-500, 10CuCe-SF-700 and 10CuCe-SF-800), the percentage of Ce3+ increase with calcination temperature increasing from 300 to 700°C, thus implying the more oxygen vacancy defects were formed with the increase of calcination temperature. However, the percentage of Ce3+ in 10CuCe-SF-800 decreased to a great degree. This phenomenon can be explained as follows: on the one hand, the copper species were migrated from the lattice of CeO2 to the surface and were sintered to form bulk CuO during high temperature calcination, thereby reducing the lattice distortion. On the other hand, the larger particle size is not conducive to forming oxygen vacancy defects within 10CuCe-SF-800. As for the latter series of XCuCe-SF-700 catalysts (5CuCe-SF-700, 7.5CuCe-SF-700 and 10CuCe-SF-700), the changes in the percentage of Ce3+ are similar to those of 10CuCe-SF-T catalysts (10CuCe-SF-300, 10CuCe-SF-500, 10CuCe-SF-700 and 10CuCe-SF-800). The percentages of Ce3+ within them are as follow: 7.5CuCe-SF-700>10CuCe-SF-700>5CuCe-SF-700, thus indicating the most oxygen vacancy defects were formed within 7.5CuCe-SF-700. 3.2 Effect of preparation method 3.2.1 Catalytic performances It was proved that the synthesis route plays an important role in determining the adsorption and catalytic behaviors of materials [56–59]. Catalytic activities of 7.5CuCe-SF-700 for CO-PROX and compare them with those of CuO-CeO2 catalyst samples prepared with other three methods (named as 7.5CuCe-UGC-700, 7.5CuCe-SG-700, and 7.5CuCe-ST-700) are illustrated in Fig. 11 . It is noticeable that the preparation method is one of the most significant factors affecting catalytic properties of these four CuO-CeO2 catalysts. The conversions of CO over them are in the order of 7.5CuCe-SF-700>7.5CuCe-UGC-700>7.5CuCe-SG–700>7.5CuCe-ST-700, and the corresponding temperature for maximum CO conversion is achieved at 120°C (100%), 140°C (100%), 180°C (100%) and 180°C (91%), respectively. As can be seen from Fig. 11B, the CO2 selectivity of 7.5CuCe-SF-700 is comparable to those of 7.5CuCe-UGC-700, 7.5CuCe-SG-700 and 7.5CuCe-ST-700 during the reaction temperature range from 60 to 120°C. However, during the reaction temperature between 120 and 180°C, the corresponding CO2 selectivity of 7.5CuCe-SF-700 is lower than those of the latter three (7.5CuCe-UGC-700, 7.5CuCe-SG-700 and 7.5CuCe-ST-700) catalysts. The 7.5CuCe-SF-700 catalyst exhibits the maximum conversion of CO, and the corresponding selectivity of CO2 especially in low-temperature region (60–120°C) is comparable to those of 7.5CuCe-UGC-700, 7.5CuCe-SG-700 and 7.5CuCe-ST-700. In other words, 7.5CuCe-SF-700 exhibits more excellent performances for CO-PROX than 7.5CuCe-UGC-700, 7.5CuCe-SG-700 and 7.5CuCe-ST-700 in low-temperature region. Accordingly, differences in the catalytic behaviors of 7.5CuCe-SF-700 and the latter three catalysts would be further investigated and characterized. 3.2.2 Characterization of catalysts BET specific surface areas of 7.5CuCe-UGC-700, 7.5CuCe-SG-700, 7.5CuCe-ST-700 and 7.5CuCe-SF-700 are summarized in Table S2. It is noted that BET specific surface area of 7.5CuCe-SF-700 is far larger than those of 7.5CuCe-UGC-700, 7.5CuCe-SG-700 and 7.5CuCe-ST-700, however, there is no significant difference in the BET specific surface area among 7.5CuCe-UGC-700, 7.5CuCe-SG-700 and 7.5CuCe-ST-700. By combining the results of their catalytic activities (Fig. 11) which exhibit the conversions of CO over these three catalysts are in the order of 7.5CuCe-UGC-700>7.5CuCe-SG-700>7.5CuCe-ST-700, therefore, it should be deduced that specific surface area is not the dominant reason for affecting catalytic performances of these CuO-CeO2 catalysts for CO preferential oxidation. This conclusion also applies to 10CuCe-SF-T and XCuCe-SF-700 catalysts. From Table 3, the SBET of 10CuCe-SF-T is decreased with the calcination temperature from 300 to 800°C, which is incompatible with their catalytic activities. Accordingly, in the following section of the paper, XRD, H2-TPR and XPS were employed to investigate the potential reasons brought about the difference in the catalytic behaviors among the four catalysts. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of 7.5CuCe-UGC-700, 7.5CuCe-SG-700, 7.5CuCe-ST-700 as well as 7.5CuCe-SF-700 are shown in Fig. S2 (in Supplementary material). Nine diffraction peaks (2θ=28.5, 33.1, 47.5, 56.3, 59.1, 69.4, 76.7, 79.1 and 88.5°), indexed to (111), (200), (220), (311), (222), (400), (331), (420) and (422) plane reflections of CeO2 cubic fluorite structure (ICDD 34-0394), are observed for all the four catalysts. However, two diffractions peaks (2θ=35.6 and 38.8°) assigned to the phases of CuO are expressed in the XRD patterns of the former three catalysts (7.5CuCe-UGC-700, 7.5CuCe-SG-700 and 7.5CuCe-ST-700) rather than that of 7.5CuCe-SF-700. The results suggest that the agglomeration of Cu species accompanied with the formation of bulk CuO on the surface of 7.5CuCe-UGC-700, 7.5CuCe-SG-700 and 7.5CuCe-ST-700, but not for 7.5CuCe-SF-700. Furthermore, as can be seen from Table S2, the crystallites size of 7.5CuCe-UGC-700, 7.5CuCe-SG-700 and 7.5CuCe-ST-700 is bigger than that of 7.5CuCe-SF-700. The larger BET surface area together with the smaller crystallites size of 7.5CuCe-SF-700 might be closely associated with the fact that lots of gases were produced and released from the transparent viscous gel within a short time, as depicted by using Eqs. (3) and (4). (3) 3Cu(NO3)2 +5CO(NH2)2 =3CuO+5CO2(g)+8N2(g)+10H2O(g) (4) 2Ce(NO3)3 +5CO(NH2)2 +0.5O2 =5CeO2 +5CO2(g)+8N2(g)+10H2O(g) These gases not only can effectively prevent the aggregation and growth of crystal particles but also are beneficial to form more pore structure and larger surface with the aid of gas rapid release. Fig. S3 gives the H2-TPR profiles of 7.5CuCe-UGC-700, 7.5CuCe-SG-700, 7.5CuCe-ST-700 and 7.5CuCe-SF-700 (in Supplementary material). It is clear that H2 consumption peak assigned to the reduction of bulk CuO is observed in the profiles of 7.5CuCe-UGC-700, 7.5CuCe-SG-700 and 7.5CuCe-ST-700, but not for 7.5CuCe-SF-700, which are excellent consistent with the results obtained from XRD characterization. As can be seen by comparing Fig.S2, all the H2 consumption peaks of 7.5CuCe-UGC-700, 7.5CuCe-SG-700 and 7.5CuCe-ST-700 shift to the higher temperature with respect to 7.5CuCe-SF-700, thus indicating the reducibility of Cu species within 7.5CuCe-UGC-700, 7.5CuCe-SG-700 and 7.5CuCe-ST-700 is lower than that of 7.5CuCe-SF-700, which might be responsible for lower catalytic activities of them. Ce 3d core level XP spectra of the four samples (7.5CuCe-SF-700, 7.5CuCe-ST-700, 7.5CuCe-UGC-700 and 7.5CuCe-SG-700) are displayed in Fig. S4 (in Supplementary material), and the corresponding ratio of Ce3+/(Ce3+ +Ce4+) within them are also summarized in Table S2 (in Supplementary material). As can be seen from Table S2, the corresponding ratios of Ce3+/(Ce3+ +Ce4+) for these four catalysts are in the order of 7.5CuCe-SF-700>7.5CuCe-UGC-700>7.5CuCe-SG-700>7.5CuCe-ST-700, which is excellent in agreement with their catalytic activities. The rapid oxidation-reduction reaction between nitrates (Ce(NO3)3 and Cu(NO3)2) and urea would be responsible for the formation of more Ce3+ ions within 7.5CuCe-SF-700, as described by Eqs. of (3) and (4). 3.3 Catalytic stability The stability of the catalyst under actual reaction conditions is of great significance to its industrial application [7,60–63]. Therefore, the experiment of 200h time-on-stream was carried out to investigate the stability of 7.5CuCe-SF-700 under the actual reaction systems contained 15% CO2 and 10% H2O, and the corresponding results of CO conversion accompanied with the selectivity of CO2 are displayed in Fig. 12 . Noticeably, there was no decline in the conversion of CO during the first 10h test. More important, more than 92% of initial CO conversion was still maintained even after 200h time-on-stream test. Furthermore, the CO2 selectivity of 7.5CuCe-SF-700 during the whole time-on-stream test is comparable to and slightly higher than that of the initial selectivity. In short, the catalyst 7.5CuCe-SF-700 exhibited excellent stability for CO preferential oxidation. In addition, there are no obvious changes in the crystal phase and crystal size after reaction (Fig. S5). The binding energy greater than 933.1eV and shake-up peak becomes stronger after 200h on-stream test (Fig. S5), indicating that Cu2+ species increased on the surface of this catalyst after the reaction, which should be results in the reduction of catalytic activity [64]. 4 Conclusions In summary, XCuCe-SF-T catalyst samples (X=5, 7.5, 10 and 15; T=300, 500, 700 and 800) were rapidly synthesized (within 30min) and estimated for CO preferential oxidation (CO-PROX). The research results show that the effect of calcination temperature on catalytic performances is more significant than that of Cu loading. The conversion of CO over 10CuCe-SF-T catalysts increases with the increasing calcination temperature from 300 to 700°C, whereas the decrease in the conversion of CO is observed with further increasing calcination temperature up to 800°C. The conversion of CO slight increases with the increase of Cu loading of from 5wt.% to 7.5wt.%, whereas the slight decline in the conversion of CO is detected with further increasing the loading of Cu from 7.5wt.% to 15wt.%. The optimal calcination temperature and the loading of Cu are 700°C and 7.5wt.%, respectively. The 7.5CuCe-SF-700 catalyst exhibits the highest catalytic performance for CO-PROX, and the corresponding temperature window for complete conversion of CO is as wide as 50°C. According to the characterization results, the 7.5CuCe-SF-700 catalyst exhibits highest catalytic activities due to the synergistic effects of high dispersion Cu species and CeO2, and the presence of more reduced copper species as the active site of the catalyst. The formation of oxygen vacancy defects and reduced copper species is closely associated with the incorporation of Cu species into the lattice of CeO2 rather than the accumulation and aggregation of Cu species on the surface. The catalytic performances of 7.5CuCe-SF-700 are better than those of 7.5CuCe-ST-700, 7.5CuCe-UGC-700 and 7.5CuCe-SG-700, which were prepared with surfactant template, urea gelation/co-precipitation and sol-gel methods, respectively. The difference between 7.5CuCe-SF-700 and the latter three catalysts would be related to the facts that Cu species of 7.5CuCe-SF-700 were highly dispersed on its surface. Thereby it strengthening the interaction between Cu species and the support CeO2. Based on the experiment of time-on-stream test, 7.5CuCe-SF-700 displays excellent stability under the actual reaction conditions (15% CO2 and 10% H2O within the reaction system) for CO-PROX. coredata.dc:description: A facile and solvent-free route has been developed to rapidly synthesize CuO-CeO2 catalysts within 30min. The effect of calcination temperature on catalytic performances is more significant than Cu loading, and the optimal calcination temperature and Cu loading are 700°C and 7.5wt.%, respectively. The optimal catalyst 7.5CuCe-SF-700 exhibits the highest CO conversion and the corresponding temperature window for full CO conversion is as wide as 50°C. According to the characterization results of XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption, H2-TPR, TEM, HR-TEM, STEM, EDS, Raman and XPS, it can be concluded that the high-performances of CuO-CeO2 catalyst should be attributed to synergistic effects of high dispersion Cu species and CeO2, and the presence of more reduced copper species as the active site in the catalyst. 7.5CuCe-SF-700 exhibits excellent stability for CO-PROX during the 200 time-on-stream test under actual reaction conditions (with 15% CO2 and 10% H2O). In addition, surfactant template, urea gelation/co-precipitation and sol-gel methods were used to synthesize CuO-CeO2 catalysts so as to compare them with 7.5CuCe-SF-700, and the results exhibit not only 7.5CuCe-SF-700 is superior to the former three catalysts but also our synthesis route is more simple, controllable, solvent-free, time-saving and energy-saving.
coredata.dc:title: A solvent-free method to rapidly synthesize CuO-CeO2 catalysts to enhance their CO preferential oxidation: Effects of Cu loading and calcination temperature
